Ao Lie chuckles at the idea of Macaque being afraid of snakes. "But you're a magic immortal monkey," he says, still laughing.

Macaque shrugs. "Even magic immortals can have their fears. And snakes have always been a weakness of mine. But enough about me. What about you, Ao Lie? What are you afraid of?"

Ao Lie hesitates for a moment before answering. "I'm afraid of going back to that underground prison. I'm afraid of being trapped again, with no hope of escape."

Macaque nods in understanding. "That's a valid fear, and it's completely understandable given what you've been through. But you're not alone anymore. You have us now, and we won't let anything happen to you."

Ao Lie looks up at Macaque, grateful for his words. "Thank you," he says softly.

Macaque pats him on the shoulder. "Anytime, my friend. And remember, fear is a natural part of being human. It's how we face those fears that defines us."

Macaque tells Ao Lie that he has his own fears - fears of failing again when they face Spider Queen, fear of letting Wukong down in a fight, and (he adds with a chuckle) a mild fear of snakes. Let's write that scene with details and dialogue and include what Macaque says.

Macaque sat there for a few moments, deep in thought. "You know, Ao Lie," he finally said, "I have my own fears too. I'm afraid of failing again when we face the Spider Queen. I'm afraid of letting Wukong down in a fight. And..." he trailed off, a small smile spreading across his face. "I'm afraid of snakes."

Ao Lie blinked in surprise. "You're afraid of snakes? But you're a legendary immortal monkey! How can you be afraid of something like that?"

Macaque chuckled. "I know, it's silly, isn't it? But I can't help it. There's just something about them that gives me the creeps. I've been trying to work on overcoming it, though. Maybe someday I'll be able to face a snake without feeling scared."

Ao Lie nodded, feeling a little better. It was reassuring to know that even someone as powerful as Macaque had fears and doubts. "Thanks, Macaque," he said. "I appreciate you talking to me. I'm still scared, but it helps to know that I'm not alone."

"Of course, Ao Lie," Macaque said, patting him gently on the back. "We're all in this together. And I know you'll be able to overcome your fears too. You're stronger than you think."

Macaque tells Ao Lie that he too has his own fears. "Fears of failing again when we face the Spider Queen, fears of letting down Wukong in a fight," he confesses, before adding with a chuckle, "and a mild fear of snakes, believe it or not."

Ao Lie laughs in disbelief, unable to imagine a legendary magic immortal monkey like Macaque being afraid of anything.

Macaque just shrugs. "Fears make us human, or in my case, a monkey. It's nothing to be ashamed of," he says, offering a comforting smile. "The important thing is how we handle them. You faced your fear of being underground and being trapped again today. You did what you had to do, and you saved our skins. That's nothing to sneeze at."

Ao Lie smiles back, grateful for the monkey's words of encouragement. "Thanks, Macaque. You always know what to say," he says.

Macaque winks. "It comes with the immortality, kid," he says with a chuckle.

Night: Ao Lie can't sleep; he goes to the training room and finds Macaque practicing with his staff and watches, fascinated. Macaque notices him watching and keeps going. Let's write that scene with details and dialogue.

Ao Lie quietly enters the training room, careful not to disturb Macaque, who's in the middle of practicing with his staff. He stands in the corner, watching as Macaque effortlessly twirls the staff around his body. Macaque seems lost in concentration, but he notices Ao Lie out of the corner of his eye.

Without breaking his rhythm, he speaks. "Can't sleep either, Ao Lie?"

Ao Lie nods, watching the staff move in Macaque's hands. "No, I couldn't," he says softly. "I'm always afraid of what's coming next."

Macaque continues his practice, moving with a fluid grace. "Fear is natural," he says. "It's what we do with it that counts."

Ao Lie watches in awe as Macaque expertly twirls the staff around his back and catches it in one hand. "But how do you manage it?" he asks.

Macaque shrugs. "I don't always manage it," he admits. "Sometimes I let my fear control me. But other times, I use it to drive me forward, to push myself to be better. Fears make us human - or in my case, a monkey."

Ao Lie nods, taking in Macaque's words. "I want to be able to do that," he says. "To use my fear to drive me forward."

Macaque nods, coming to a stop in front of Ao Lie. "It takes practice," he says, handing Ao Lie the staff. "But I think you have what it takes."

Ao Lie enters the training room, surprised to find Macaque there. The monkey is moving fluidly, twirling his staff and striking the air with precise, lightning-fast movements. Ao Lie can't help but be captivated by the display, watching Macaque's every move with rapt attention.

Macaque notices Ao Lie's presence but doesn't stop his training. He moves gracefully, his body fluid and controlled as he spins and flips his staff with ease. The sound of the staff slicing through the air fills the room.

Finally, Macaque finishes his routine by tossing his staff into the air and catching it with a flourish. He bows toward Ao Lie with a smile.

"Beautiful," Ao Lie says, clapping his hands together. "I had no idea you were such an accomplished fighter."

Macaque chuckles. "Fighting is only part of it, my friend. This staff is an extension of my body, a tool for meditation and focus. I train to keep my mind sharp, my body limber, and my spirit strong."

Ao Lie nods, impressed. "It's amazing. I wish I could move like that."

Macaque grins. "Don't sell yourself short. You have your own strengths, your own unique abilities. You'll find your own path."

Ao Lie smiles, feeling encouraged. "Thanks, Macaque. I needed to hear that."

Macaque puts a hand on Ao Lie's shoulder. "Remember, fear can be a powerful motivator. But it can also hold you back. Embrace your fears, acknowledge them, and then move beyond them. It's what makes us human - or in my case, a monkey."

Ao Lie laughs, feeling a weight lifted off his shoulders. "I'll try to remember that."

Macaque nods, then picks up his staff again. "Now, would you like to try a few moves?"

They train together for a bit until Ao Lie needs a break. Macaque has barely broken a sweat. They sit, and Ao Lie notices Macaque's spider bite scar again, exposed by his short-sleeved tunic. Let's write that scene with details and dialogue.

Ao Lie takes a deep breath and breaks the silence. "Macaque, can I ask you something personal?"

Macaque raises an eyebrow. "Of course," he says, sitting up straighter.

Ao Lie hesitates for a moment before continuing. "Your spider bite scar, does it still hurt?"

Macaque looks down at the scar on his arm, tracing the jagged lines with his finger. "No, it doesn't hurt anymore," he replies. "But it serves as a reminder of a time when I was not as careful as I should have been."

Ao Lie nods, understanding. "You know, I've been thinking about what you said earlier, about facing our fears. I'm still scared of the dark, of being trapped underground, and of spiders."

Macaque nods, listening intently.

"But watching you train, seeing how fearless you are, I think I want to face my fears too," Ao Lie continues. "I want to learn from you, to become stronger."

Macaque chuckles, a warm smile spreading across his face. "Fears make us human, or in my case, a monkey. But facing them and overcoming them is what makes us truly powerful."

Ao Lie nods, feeling inspired. "Thank you, Macaque. I think I'm ready to start training harder, to become a better fighter."

Macaque puts a hand on Ao Lie's shoulder. "I'm here to help you, as is Wukong and Bai Long Ma. We'll face our fears together and come out stronger for it."
